chunks.text: In this tutorial, I'll show you what Blume is and how you can add it to your renders so they look nicer.

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: To get good results with your Blume, I recommend having HDR colors enabled so that you can get more variation in your Blume effects.

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: So if you don't know what Blume is, here it is.

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: As you can see, Blume is that aura-like color around bright lights that gives them the appearance of being brighter than they really are in reality.

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: The theoretical steps of achieving this are really simple.

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: What you want to do is to render your image as you usually do,

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: except you'll also render all the bright spots of your image in another texture.

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: Now that these two are separated, we want to blur the second texture.

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: The algorithm you use to blur the texture and the steps you take in doing so will define the quality and look of your Blume.

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: Once that is done, you simply slap the second texture onto the first one and you're done.

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: To start off, you want to create a second texture for your post-processing buffer.

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: Make sure you attach it to the second spot of the frame buffer using gel color attachment one.

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: Now to tell open gel that we'll want to draw to both textures, we'll have to use gel draw buffers,

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: passing an array with the attachments used.

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: Then we need to specify to the fragment shader that we are outputting to two textures and assign

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: their fragment colors like so. Here I first multiply the red fragments because I want those lava

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: lines to pop out more. Then I compute the brightness by looking at the graysky value of the fragment,

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: which can be obtained through a dot product like so. And finally, I decide whether or not to accept

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: the fragment to the second texture based on its brightness. At this point of the tutorial,

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: if you bind the second texture, it should look something like this. The next step is to blur the

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: image. In this tutorial, I will use Gaussian blur since it's often used for bloom effects.

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: So I'll start by making a shader program for the blur and sending it the texture we wish to modify.

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: Now for the shader itself, we'll basically first calculate the horizontal blur of all pixels

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: and then in another run we'll calculate the vertical blur. This is done in order to improve the

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: performance of the program. If you want a more detailed explanation, go to learnopenjel.com or

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: Google the specifics of the two pass Gaussian blur method. Once your shader is ready, you need to

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: create two frame buffers each with one texture. These two frame buffers will be used to run the

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: two blur passes mentioned earlier. A deraute ping pong frame buffers because they keep passing data

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: from one to another. Now in our main loop, we want to pass the data between them. The amount of

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: times you bounce the texture will depend on how much blur you want. Notice how I check if it's

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: the first bounce since I want to use the image generated earlier for that initial pass. After that,

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: all the passing is done between the textures of the ping pong buffers. Don't forget you actually

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: tell the shader if you're doing horizontal or vertical pass using a ball. After bouncing the data

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: around the bit, you should have a blurred image similar to this. All that's left to do now is to

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: bind the color texture and the blurred texture, pass them to the post processing fragment shader,

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: and add them together. As a last step, don't forget to also apply your gamma correction and tone

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: mapping. Now if you run your program, you should have some cool neon-like bloom around the

chunks.title: Bloom.mp4
chunks.text: bright parts of your image. Do not overdo the effect though since it was overused in the 2000s
